DOC.brief_summary: Is dual-task obstacle crossing training more efficiently than single-task obstacle crossing training on the improvement of walking ability, balance ability, and lower extremity muscle strength in ambulatory subjects with spinal cord injury
DOC.brief_title: Dual-task Obstacle Crossing Training in Ambulatory Subjects With Spinal Cord Injury
DOC.detailed_description: To compare immediate effects of dual-task and single-task obstacle crossing training in ambulatory subjects with spinal cord injury
DOC.criteria: independent ambulatory subjects with traumatic causes or nonprogressive diseases subacute and chronic stage of injury (at least 3 month after injury) body mass index (BMI) between 18.529.9 kg/m2 walk independently for at least 17 meters with or without assistive devices (Functional Independence Measure Locomotor (FIML) scores 57) able to read Thai pain in the musculoskeletal system with a pain scale more than 5 out of 10 on a the visual analog scale (VAS) deformity in the joints that affect ambulatory ability unable to understand the commands and tests used in the study
